question: Consider the following item table.  How many rows will be returned by the given select query?SELECT DISTINCT category_code FROM item ORDER BY category_code;

description.Justification: Since Distinct clause considers NULL as well.Replace DISTINCT with ALL and see the difference in result!

question: Consider the following customer table.Which of the following queries would return all unique combinations of city and state from the customer table?

options.option1: SELECT DISTINCT city, DISTINCT state FROM customer ORDER BY city, state;

options.option2: SELECT DISTINCT city, state FROM customer ORDER BY city, state;

options.option3: SELECT DISTINCT (city, state) FROM customer ORDER BY city, state;

options.option4: SELECT DISTINCT city, state FROM customer ORDER BY DISTINCT city, state;

description.A: Wrong since DISTINCT keyword is duplicated
description.B: Correct as DISTINCT is properly used with multiple columns

question: Consider a table Student - RollNo, Name, Marks and the query given below.SELECT RollNo, Name FROM Student  WHERE Marks BETWEEN 80 AND 90; The query will return the roll number and names of those students where marks________

description.Justification: between considers both lower and upper limit values as well

question: Consider the following customer table and the incomplete query given below. SELECT * FROM Customer WHERE ____________________________;  Identify the missing portion of the query so that while executed it gives the following result.  Select one or more applicable answers

options.option3: customer_id=1003 OR customer_id=1004 OR customer_id=1005 OR customer_id=1006

options.option5: customer_id=1003 AND customer_id=1004 AND customer_id=1005 AND customer_id=1006

question: Which of the following queries would execute without any error?  Assume that the concerned  tables are already created accordingly.

options.option1: UPDATE item SET category_code = 100 WHERE category_code IS NULL;

options.option2: UPDATE item SET category_code = 100 WHERE category_code = NULL;

options.option3: UPDATE item SET category_code = 100 WHERE category_code IN NULL;

options.option4: DELETE FROM item WHERE category_code IS NULL;

options.option5: DELETE * FROM item WHERE category_code IS NOT NULL;

options.option6: DELETE  FROM item WHERE category_code IN (NULL);
